column4: I'm trying to dualboot Ubuntu and Arch, and i'm really confused as to how to partition my HDD to do so - I've never had a dual boot before, any help?
Can you ask a more specific question?
I can help.
Sure

Each distro will have a set of mount points.  These are pointers to partitions.  Each distro needs some mountpoints to boot (specifically / and swap).  Some partitions can be used by more than one distro (swap).  Some cannot.  The whole thing becomes more complicated if you have a separate /home).

So on the 120 Gb HDD.  You'll need two roots (one for ubuntu, one for arch), an optional /home, and a swap.  The other hdd you can just partition and make mountpoints in the OS's later after they're installed
for example, if you hibernate ubuntu but then boot arch it will probs not boot well or the hibernation will be lost as best

'root' is a mountpoint.  You should just create one big empty partition on the 80Gb.  It is not used as a root partition
Ubuntu won't let you modify partitions that are mounted and the root partition cannot be unmounted

Use ext4 for everything.

Arch is hard no doubt.
But, if you install arch first, use the entire disc, then install Ubuntu.  Ubuntu will give you the option to install side-by-side with arch without messing it up
The other order does not work because arch does not have such a feature built into their installer (although you can do it manually).
Each distro installed needs a root and a swap.  So for each installer create an ext4 partition and mount it at root.  Then create a swap for each OS as well
